title: Are 'more perfect' and 'most perfect' correct? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would say”more perfect” and “most perfect” are incorrect. Or more incorrect or most incorrect. “Perfect” means, well, perfect. It cannot not be better. Nothing can be better that “perfect”. If something was better that whatever was “perfect” then what was was called “perfect” was not “perfect”. “Perfect” means 100%. There is no 100.00001% . So nothing can be “more perfect”. It can only be “better” than anything else except “perfect”. “Most perfect” would mean that something would be “better” than the “best”, in which case the “best” would be worse that the “better”, which cannot be. “More perfect” is “better”. And “Most perfect” is best. The “better” and the best” may or may not be “perfect”. You could have two “perfects”, in which case they would be “equal”. Do I make myself most perfectly clear?

Certainly. English often treats absolute adjectives (ones that either apply or don’t) as gradable (more or less applicable). For example, complete is often called absolute: a job is either complete or it isn’t. But we don’t hesitate to say almost complete or nearly complete or even put a number on it and say 75% complete, like a software upgrade. This reintroduces gradability, and we can understand more complete as meaning ‘more nearly complete, closer to completion’. If John’s work is 75% done and Mary’s work only 50% done, it is legitimate to say “John’s work is more complete than Mary’s work.” However, more perfect union is a red herring: the word perfect in that sense does not mean ‘ideal’ but in fact ‘complete’: the more perfect union sought by the constitutional convention was a more complete union between the U.S. states. Similarly, infinite often means in ordinary language ‘very, very large’ rather than ‘endless, unbounded’, and so nearly infinite is a sensible notion.

Both are incorrect. Perfect denotes a state that can’t be improved upon, so a comparative and superlative are impossible and illogical. Just as one can be dead but not more dead or most dead, a thing can be perfect but not more perfect or most perfect. (If someone is being colloquial and rapturous, s/he might say, “That is the most perfect thing I’ve ever seen!” and good manners would prevent you from correcting him/her.) Yes, I know that more perfect union appears in that sacrosanct American document, but usage changes over time and in 2018, you may not modify perfect if you want to be grammatical.

Under certain circumstances the meaning of a word is not to be taken so literally. Just like how “real, wrong” can have multiple layers of connotation when used in specific ways i.e. I hoped it was a dream, but the experience couldn’t have been more real. It is wrong to divest a person of his precious freedom, but it is even more wrong to take his heart. (Maybe not too convincing example sentences here) Anyway, here is where “perfect” can have a more gradable meaning:- During his performance the piece was so cleanly executed, so heavenly it left his audience enthralled - it couldn’t have been any more perfect. [perfect is closer to “great”, “magical” in this sense] However, it is still not possible to use “perfect” in comparative and superlative forms when the word has an “extreme” sort of connotation and does not allow for gradations in meaning. ‘He earned a perfect score on his most recent maths test’ [I cannot imagine what a ‘more perfect score’ than an already ‘perfect’ score (100%) would be] Hope it helped!

Certainly.  And the issue is not over perfect being an absolute, but rather that more and most have multiple meanings.  The US Constitution is a canonical work of writing so "more perfect" is correct by premise.  The meaning is clear too, it's just an inverted use of "more" to mean approaching the quality of the adjective it modifies, not expanding on the quality - in other words, closer to.  Similarly, in "most perfect" the word most means "closest to" rather than "having the greatest amount of". Next stop, "nearly perfect" and "nearly infinite".  What do those mean?

I don’t believe so, in my personal opinion. To me, perfection means something definite. You can’t be more or less perfect. You either are or are not (although I don’t like using the word at all). Not only that, but saying “more” or “most perfect” sounds strange. “Perfecter” and “perfectest” sound even stranger. The first options may be grammatically correct, but not logically correct. So no, I don’t think using perfect like that is widely accepted.

I would think that it would be acceptable. It is one of those many words that appears to be 'an absolute' but depends largely upon context. For example, in both philosophy as well as science + mathematic there are degrees of what is seen as absolute in quotidian reality. Specifically, in math + physics, there are notions of smaller, larger + greater infinities depending upon the scale of reference. One also has countable infinities as well as uncountable. Likewise, ideologies also surface be it finitism, intuitionism, constructivism, etc. Where one might get into grey areas would be physical states of being such as pregnancy, death, illness, evil, etc. However, I would aver that in many cases there could arguably be a case for degree of said quality.
There is no such thing as “more perfect.” It's either perfect or the most perfect. These two options are the only options that are grammatically correct.

There are some quality adjectives that do not admit of different degrees and therefore cannot be compared: eternal, perfect, round, square, unique, universal. We cannot say more perfect, more round, more square.
